characters: WILL, GET THE HELL OFF OF ME
MIGHT WANT TO LOOK TO YOUR RIGHT,
IT WAS JUST AN APRIL FOOL'S JOKE
BLOW HIS BRAINS OUT WITHOUT EVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julianne Moore walks out into the street. Sam Jackson resumes narrating to the best of his ability.

dialogues.speaker: SAM JACKSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now, like any great hero, our hero wasn’t perfect. Far from it. Julianne lights a cigarette, tries to hail a CAB.

dialogues.speaker: SAM JACKSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She smoked, first of all, which they normally don’t let you show in movies any more even though we all still smoke sometimes... oh don’t even start, you know you smoke sometimes. You and the wife have a date night, you each have two martinis, you guys are feeling wild so you buy a pack of smokes on the way home and you each smoke one in the 7-Eleven parking lot. Then she makes you throw out the pack, but instead of throwing it out you hide it in a plant outside the house and some nights, after she goes to sleep, you sneak out and have one. But then one night she catches you when you come to bed, ‘cause she smells that shit on you like she’s a detective - she smells that shit on you like she’s Jimmy Smits in “NYPD Blue” and she’s cracked the fucking case - and you get in a big fight and-- WHAT IN THE FUCK!? As Sam has been telling this story, we’ve been watching Julianne Moore trying to catch a cab. Having no luck, she has ventured further and further into street and, at exactly the time of Sam’s “WHAT THE FUCK”, gotten run over by a bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit! Oh shit! Julianne Moore just got straight up run over by the bus! People run to the scene of the accident...

dialogues.speaker: SAM JACKSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Maybe she’s okay, maybe she’s just lying under the bus dazed. A GOOD SAMARITAN (30s) takes charge, starts motioning for bus to back up.

dialogues.speaker: GOOD SAMARITAN
dialogues.text: Back up the bus! Back it up!

dialogues.speaker: SAM JACKSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She's gonna be fine. She’s our hero and she’s gonna be fine-- OH

dialogues.speaker: ON JULIANNE
dialogues.text: Completely smushed. It’s like something out of “Walking Dead” but worse. The Good Samaritan starts VOMITING and spectators start SCREAMING and CRYING. A LITTLE HISPANIC BOY inside the bus presses his face to window. His eyes well with tears. As more people gather, a man pushes through, out of the crowd... It’s SAM JACKSON. Right before passing through frame he says...

dialogues.speaker: SAM JACKSON
dialogues.text: Fuck this, I’m out.

dialogues.speaker: A COMPUTER SCREEN
dialogues.text: We see exactly that, the words typed in screenplay format SAM JACKSON (CONT’D) Fuck this, I’m out. We are in...  INT. STARBUCKS —- MORNING Our REAL HERO is writing the bizarre screenplay we’ve bee watching. Note: it’s the Good Samaritan from the accident. A real NARRATOR (female) takes over:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Will Dempsey was thirty-one years old when he finally gave up on his Sam Jackson unreliable narrator screenplay. (beat) He’d been working on it since 7:30 AM. Will looks up at the clock. It’s 7:47 AM. Will closes the computer, stands, heads to the counter. A way-too-chipper FEMALE BARISTA greets him.

dialogues.speaker: BARISTA
dialogues.text: Top of the morning to you, good Sir! What can I get for you!?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Double espresso, large cup.

dialogues.speaker: BARISTA
dialogues.text: And would you care for anything to eat?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: A fuck you?

dialogues.speaker: BARISTA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (big smile) I said “no thank you.”

dialogues.speaker: BARISTA
dialogues.text: (confused) Oh, okay, right.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: ("thank you so much”) Fuck you so much. She looks up, confused. Did she just hear that again?  But Will is just smiling big at her. She gives up, takes his cash.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Will was not well. But you don’t need me to tell you that. Will stands in the waiting area. Out of nowhere, he start SINGING. Loudly. People stare. He’s singing Bob Dylan's Standing in the Doorway.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (doing Dylan) I’m walking through, the summer nights/The jukebox, playing low. Yesterday everything, was going too fast/Today it’s moving too slow...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (calling out) Will!? Will jolts to a stop. A SECOND BARISTA is holding out his now-ready coffee. Will approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BARISTA
dialogues.text: Double espresso, large cup?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yeppers. Will takes the large cup. Opens the lid. From his back pocket he takes out a small glass BOTTLE OF WHISKEY and pours the whole thing into the cup. He does a long pour. Announces it:

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (loudly) I’m doing a long pour. Everyone in the Starbucks is now watching him. Will reaches into his pocket, takes out a PILL BOTTLE. He removes a pill, downs it, turns back to the barista.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Want one?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BARISTA
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s Xanax.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BARISTA
dialogues.text: Still no.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Boo humbug.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BARISTA
dialogues.text: (correcting) Bah humbug.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: That’s what she said.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BARISTA
dialogues.text: Huh? Will SHRUGS, starts singing another verse:

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I got no way left to turn/I got nothing left to burn... (then) It’s Dylan, people! Standing in the Doorway! Third track on Time out of Mind. His comeback album. The whole thing’s like a giant fucking Keats poem. (a beat, then) Give it a chance, it’1l grow on you. A STARBUCKS MANAGER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh man. Are you gonna make me leave? Bah humbug. Will gives a proud thumbs up to the second barista ("nail it.”) CUE SONG: Bob Dylan’s Standing in the Doorway. SLOW MOTION ACTION as the manager and other Starbucks employees push/carry Will out of the store... Just before he’s out the door, Will yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m telling you: give it a chance, it will grow on you! From somewhere unknown, a WOMAN’S VOICE echoes Will's: WOMAN’S VOICE (PRE-LAP) (laughing) Just give it a chance, it will grow on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow an adorable MINI GOLDENDOODLE into a sun-kissed bedroom. The same BOB DYLAN SONG is playing.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It will grow on me? He sounds like he’s suffering. WOMAN’S VOICE (0O.S.) Bob Dylan does not sound like he’s suffering.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well he doesn’t sound like he’s singing. The OFF-SCREEN WOMAN LAUGHS. WOMAN’S VOICE (0.S.) You're a heathen. The dog tries hopping up on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (loving) C'mere, Fuckface. The mini Goldendoodle does in fact wear a nametag reading “Fuckface.” Hands reach down, pull the dog up. The hands belong to... WILL (in bed) The Will of six months ago is a different Will - fresh fa sober, and handsome. Happy.  10.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Will hadn’t always been “not well.” It had really only been since his wife had left him that... (then) You know what, we’ll get to that. Right now let’s enjoy them as they were. Will turns over with the dog and faces his wife... ABBY DEMPSEY (30, knockout).

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Will loved his wife Abby with an intensity usually reserved for stalkers. She was everything a man could ask for in a wife. She was nurturing, and she was beautiful, and she ate any kind of sushi the chef served to her, even the uni. (then) Yes, Will was sure of it: Abby Dempsey was absolutely perfect. At least back then she was. Abby takes the dog from Will.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, just listen to this next song for thirty seconds and tell me Bob Dylan is not a poet.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You have been listening to this man gargling for a month straight.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I'm in a phase, Baby. C’mon, lean into this with me. It’s Dylan’s comeback album! Abby sits up, animated.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They were counting him out, Man! They said you don’t come back from the crazy he had and then... BOOM! 1997. Time Out of Mind! Three Grammys, Album of the Year, he told everyone “I’m Bob Dylan and you’re not so eat a dick.”  11.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Bob Dylan told everyone to “eat a dick?”

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Metaphorically, yes, he did. (then) Listen to this track. Really listen, then tell me he’s not a poet. I read this literary analysis online, they say he drew on the poetry of Keats-- Will fakes SNORING.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C’mon, Babe, this is important to me. Will opens his eyes, looks at her. He loves her so completely that it practically seeps from his pores. He nods. She smiles, hits a button on her iPod. CUE SONG: Not Dark Yet by Bob Dylan. A new Dylan song fills the room. They sit there for thirt seconds, listening. At a certain point, Abby simply close her eyes and sings along, swaying. Will just watches her. Smitten. Always smitten.

dialogues.speaker: BOB DYLAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There’s not even room enough, to be anywhere/It’s not dark yet, but it’s getting there. Abby stops the song. Opens her eyes. Will smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (knowingly) Don't.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: He sounds like he has a giant cock lodged in his throat. She playfully smacks him with a pillow.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Asshole!  12. Will rolls on top of her. They wrestle playfully, until..

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, wait, watch Fuckface, are we rolling on Fuckface? Will, careful. Will sits up. Abby rolls out from under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm starving. I need to shower or we’re gonna be late for your parents. As she stands we realize Abby is very pregnant. Explosive pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hey? Abby turns. Pregnant, hair in her face, luminous.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MUCH YOUNGER ABBY (20) dances with a HOT GUY on a sweat beer soaked dance floor. A MUCH YOUNGER WILL (21) stands holding two beers behind them.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hey! They don’t hear Will over the music.

dialogues.speaker: I GOT YOU A BEER
dialogues.text: Abby and Hot Guy stop dancing, turn.

dialogues.speaker: HOT GUY
dialogues.text: Thanks, man! Hot Guy takes both beers and hands one to Abby. She smiles apologetically at Will and resumes dancing wit the other guy.  13. Will watches, either devastated or nonplussed. You can never quite tell with Will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits on the stairs, watching the party absentmindedl nursing a beer. A beautiful pair of legs steps into his sightline. He smi without even looking up. Abby sits down next to him into frame. They face forward, watching the party.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: What happened to Fuckface?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Tim.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: If you say so. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t into him.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh. Too bad for Fuckface.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Tim.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Sure. A beat. They watch Tim/Fuckface dance with a new girl.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He looks like one of those Valentine’s Day stuffed animals, doesn’t he? Like one of those perfect fluffy teddy bear dogs things with the button eyes?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You jealous?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Just observant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (small smile) If you say so. A beat. They sip their beers in contented silence.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you ever going to ask me out, Will?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Just waiting for the right moment.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. Good to know. Another long beat. They sip their beers.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You might want to get on it, is all. Because I’m contemplating going home with Tim--

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Fuckface.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Both of them, out of sheer loneliness.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Okay. Good to know. (then) But I’m still waiting for the right moment. She SIGHS, frustrated, stands.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I'll see you later, Will. She turns to go. Will calls after her.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for the right moment, Abby, because once I ask you out, there won’t be any turning back for me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I won’t date anyone else for the rest of my life, I won’t love anyone else for the rest of my life, I won’t really care about anything else for the rest of my life. I am going to fall in love with you with such intensity that I may not be able to think straight for the next few decades. I’m waiting for the right moment, Abby, because when I ask you out it will be the most important moment of my life and I want to make sure I get it right. ON ABBY: blown away and a little stunned. Will just shrugs, casual, and sips his beer.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So that’s why.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Okay. Good to know. A charged silent beat. Abby stands to go.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Abby. She turns.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want to go to the movies with me?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (confused) Wait... are you asking me out? Will shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: The moment felt right. Abby smiles. They fall in love, instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re back to PRESENT-DAY-STARBUCKS-DRUNK WILL DEMPSEY.  16. He walks down the street, wobbling and swigging from his Starbucks cup of coffee/whiskey. He pulls an iPod from his pocket. He puts on HEADPHONES. He scrolls forward to track number 5 on Dylan’s Time Out Mind album: Trying to Get to Heaven. Instantly, all the sounds of the city vanish. We hear onl the song...

dialogues.speaker: BOB DYLAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The air is getting hotter/ there’s a rumbling in the skies/ having waded through the high muddy water/ with the heat rising in my eyes. The sights and sounds of summertime New York flood past W He takes them all in, hyper-focused on each detail: - A MAN walks his TINY DOG. - A WOMAN tries to hail a CAB. - A COUPLE holds hands while pushing a stroller.

dialogues.speaker: BOB DYLAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Every day your memory grows dimmer/it doesn’t haunt me like it did before/I’ve been walking through the middle of nowhere/trying to get to Heaven before they close the door. Will ENTERS the front REVOLVING DOOR of an office buildin He just goes around and around, never getting out. Listen to Dylan. A man at sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will sits in a chair, staring forward, almost catatonic. WOMAN’S VOICE (0O.S.) How are you doing today, Will? Will stares forward.  17. WOMAN'S VOICE (0.S.) (CONT’D) Will? Will looks up, a bit startled. REVEAL: a pretty therapist - DOCTOR KATE MORRIS (35) - sitting opposite him in a therapist’s office. Dr. Morris is attractive and has red hair. Note: this loo lot like the opening therapy scene.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, what did you say?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I asked how you were doing today.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh. You know. Same. (then) Has anyone ever told you that you look like Julianne Moore?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: You did. Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Well I’ve got a good eye because you're a dead ringer. Will sips from his alcohol filled Starbucks cup. FLASH: Young Will and Young Abby on their first date, in packed movie theatre, enjoying a re-release of “Pulp Fict with other Tarantino fanatics. Sam Jackson is screaming: “I'm a mushroom-cloud-layin' motherfucker, motherfucker” Abby is loving it. Will watches her, watching it, and tak her hand for the first time. BACK TO WILL, in therapy.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tried to masturbate the other day. I tried thinking of her, but I couldn't get it done so... This hangs there.  A beat. 18.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then I tried thinking of you, but that’s when I realized how much you look like Julianne Moore and I started thinking about what I’d seen her in last and it was “Still Alice” and then well, you know... (then) I mean, you jerk off to “Still Alice” you need to be institutionalized.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: You were institutionalized.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Touché. FLASH: Young Will and Young Abby lying in bed, post-coita He’s tracing her back with his fingers, memorizing her. BACK TO WILL, in therapy.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She left six months ago today.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I know. But you’ve been in a facility almost that entire time, Will. And I'm trying to get a sense - Will, are you listening to me? - I’m trying to get a sense of how you’re doing being back out in the world again.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Oh. You know. Same.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: You keep saying that.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I keep meaning it.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Have you spoken to her? Since you've been out? FLASH: A bleary-eyed Will sits in a fancy Italian restaur with Abby. He implores her to come back to him. She refuses, stands, and leaves - tears in her eyes.  19. BACK TO WILL, in therapy.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (lying) No. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Have you gone to see your parents yet, like we discussed?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I don’t want to.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Will, part of the reason you were discharged and put into my care was so you could start--

dialogues.speaker: I DON'T WANT TO, OKAY
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was weird. Sorry. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Yesterday you said that since you'd been discharged you’d been feeling aimless.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Well, I usually have good aim, so-- Will stops short.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: What, Will? What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLEGE-AGE WILL is participating in a SHOOTING GAME at a carnival/fair. He hits his mark. COLLEGE-AGE ABBY cheers. Will receives a TEDDY BEAR, hands it to Abby.  20.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We’ll name him Fuckface. Abby LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Every teddy bear in our lives cannot be named Fuckface.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I like reminding you of the life you could have had if I hadn’t rescued you.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (laughing) Do you now!?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (a la John Wayne) Yes, Ma‘am. Will tips an imaginary cap and blows on the gun like a gunslinger. She LAUGHS. Will grabs her and she GIGGLES/SQUIRMS. But quickly they settle into the embrace. Will looks her in the eye:

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s get married. Abby freezes ever so slightly.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: We've only been dating a few months, Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And I think I’ve shown great restraint waiting this long. She can’t help but smile.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want to say yes so bad it hurts.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You do.  21.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You’re cocky.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I’m right. She smiles. Will reaches for the toy gun. He puts it to h head, does his best John Wayne again:

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Little Lady, say yes or let me put myself out of my misery.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Stop that, c’mon.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Come on, Little Mama.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (laughing) Will, enough. Will relents, lowers the fake gun. But then... he shoves in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (mumbled ) “Yes, I will marry yo--

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Will! Will clocks her discomfort, removes the gun.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (apologetic) That was weird. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I love you, Will. You’re the love of my life, I’m sure of it. But it scares me how much... (then) It scares me how much you feel, Will. (beat) I never would have thought that could be a thing that scared me but... I may not be equipped to be loved this much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only know one way to love you, Abby.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I know, but--

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (matter-of-fact) I‘ll find another way. This stops her. Will thinks, then:

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1l find another way. I will love you however you're equipped to handle it, Abby. I will love you with restraint, I will love you on odd days of the week, I will figure out how you like your love and I will make it to order for you--

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: We'd have to get a dog. Will stops short, momentarily thrown.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I mean, I want kids too, but not for a while.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: But a dog first. A small dog.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: My parents died young and that makes me sad sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: It will probably make me a bad mother. 22.  23.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I disagree but okay.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Mainly I want the dog, that’s the big thing. A small dog.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I’m completely on board with the dog.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Okay, I’1l marry you.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Okay. Will hands Abby her Teddy Bear.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Wanna meet my parents?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens revealing: IRWIN (65) and LINDA (61) DEMPSEY, Will's delightfully ov the-top New Yorker-for-life parents. They SQUEAL with delight at the appearance of... WILL AND ABBY, 9 years aged forward since the previous sc Note: these are the pregnant, Bob Dylan loving/hating versions of Will and Abby from that morning roughly six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Abby! My God, look at you. You’re positively...

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Revolting?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: No, you’re--  24.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Gassy?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: She is pretty gassy, Ma. Will’s father nods.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: That means it’s gonna be a boy. I practically needed a hazmat suit when your mother was pregnant with you.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (nodding) It’s true. Will turns to Abby:

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: My dad says that the farts mean it’s a boy.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Well, that makes them all worth it. Abby turns to Linda.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m almost afraid to ask, but did you...

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Meatloaf just came out of the oven. Abby practically collapses in relief.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Oh, God bless you, I’ve never craved anything like this. Linda, get me to that meatloaf and you can nag, pester, and back-handedly insult me to your heart’s content. Abby ENTERS, eager. Linda follows her, equally eager.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Oh good! (getting right to it) Abby, honey? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you forget to put on socks or was that a choice? Because it’s very chilly out and... Will and his dad share a look, SHRUG, and follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four of them sit at a dining room table, eating. Abby is positively chowing on that meatloaf. Will watches her go at it. He smiles and looks off to an ADJACENT LIVING ROOM. It's already a SHRINE/PLAYGROUND for his unborn child. A crib, play toys, play area, the works.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Ma, you are aware that the kid isn’t going to actually live with you, right?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I got carried away, sue me. Here, eat, before she gets it all. Linda serves Will meatloaf. His father motions toward the baby mess.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: Baby clothes, baby swings, baby stem cells, who knows - I don’t know what half this shit is. All I know is that I spend all day breaking down the goddamn Amazon boxes.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Sshh you. Here, Honey, a little more. Linda goes to give Will more meatloaf. But Abby - without breaking stride - slaps the spoon away and takes the rest herself like an animal feeding on a kill.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to be a grandmother, I just can’t believe it. Abby, don’t take this the wrong way--  26.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: But selfishly I’m just so glad your parents are dead.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Boom.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Oh stop it, Abby knows what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: She does? (to Abby) You do?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (mouth full) She'll explain.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: What I mean is...

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (chewing) See?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: ++. all I ever wanted was for Will to marry a woman with dead parents so I didn’t have to share the grandchildren. And he did. My prayers came true.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Jesus, Ma!

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Oh, Abby knows what I mean. (then, immediate) Ooh, Abby, did you look at that book I sent you yet... As CONVERSATION CONTINUES in the background, Will looks o into that adjacent living room filled with baby products.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Both Abby’s parents died in a car accident when she was a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE - DAY Back to present-day/messed-up Will in therapy with Dr. Morris. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Abby was in the car. She was seven.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: “Okay” feels like a strange response to that new information. Dr. Morris smiles. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I was caught off guard. (then) You don’t talk about Abby a lot.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You don’t ask about her a lot.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I ask about her constantly.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Tomato, potato.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: (correcting) Tomato, tom-ah-to.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Let’s call the whole thing off.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Your sessions with me are mandated, Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No, I meant... “tomato, tom-ah-to, let's call the whole thing off.”

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I’m not following.  28.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: My God, this is some kind of rhythm we have, huh, Doc? Maybe this is why I can’t jerk off to you. A really awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (apologetic) That was way inappropriate. (explaining) I was institutionalized.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Why don’t you tell me about Abby, Will? I’d like to know more about her.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Well, then you’ve come to the right place, Doc. I am the world’s foremost expert on all things Abby. (beat, then) Or I was, I guess. (then) No, I still am, I mean it’s not like someone else learned more about her in the past six months. (then) I mean someone could have, I’ve been locked up and God only knows what she’s been up to wherever she is--

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Right. Let me tell you about Abby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABBY’S MOM gives birth. Her FATHER cheers her on. Will becomes our third narrator (so far)...

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Abby Lesher was born on June 30th, 1985. The legend goes that when she was born, she didn’t make a peep. The baby comes out. The doctor prods it. Nothing.  29.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O)
dialogues.text: For five minutes, little Abby just sat there, taking in the world. Not so much as a single cry. The baby just sits there, contented.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In the years to come, her parents would always say that there was nothing wrong with baby Abby. She just didn’t have anything to say yet. PRESENT DAY WILL steps into frame with Dr. Morris (the sc participants don’t “see” them).

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Now keep in mind, I’m getting all this second hand. I never met any of the people here except Abby.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Understood.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Her parents die. Pretty soon. Long before I come into the picture.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: No, I know.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And it’s not like I know any of these doctors or nurses, why would

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Let's move along, Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Okay. INT. ABBY’S HOME - YEARS LATER An adorable FIVE-YEAR-OLD ABBY dances in the living room. Her parents sit on a couch, watching and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O)
dialogues.text: By all accounts, Abby’s early childhood was a happy one.  30. ON HER PARENTS (40s) Adoring their child.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Her parents - Jack and Elizabeth - were kind-hearted and good-hearted and all the other kinds of “hearted.” They were literally both elementary school teachers. It’s actually how they met...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth (Abby’s mom) sits by herself eating in the teacher’s lounge. She takes a big bite of her sandwich. Just then: Jack (Abby’s dad) approaches, sits next to her

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You mind if I sit? She goes to answer, but catches herself (her mouth is ful She motions for Jack to sit, he does. She covers her mouth and continues chewing quickly.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If Abby’s mother had known she’d meet her future husband at precisely that moment, she probably wouldn’t have taken a huge bite of a peanut butter and jelly sandwich just seconds before.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Jack. She goes to respond, but is still chewing. She motions at her mouth, apologetically. Chews. He waits. And waits. She can’t get it down. They start laughing. REVEAL opposite them: Will and Dr. Morris sit at the table watching the game of peanut butter induced charades/hysterics.  31.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Now is this a meet-cute, or is this a meet-cute. (then) Screenwriting term. I’ve been writing. He watches them.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s strange to think about isn’t it? How a completely random moment involving peanut butter, a moment that happened before I was even born, shaped my entire life.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Are you glad it happened? Will watches them.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Ah, well that, Dr. Morris, is the big question, isn’t it? Because if it hadn't happened... We see all of the following in FLASHING SNAPSHOTS from th past - like a high-speed MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Abby’s parents would never have met, they’d never have married, they'd never have honeymooned in Aruba where they conceived Abby. They’d never have seen Abby come into the world without a peep, they’d never have watched her blonde hair turn brown as she got older. They’d never have watched her become obsessed with dancing, then soccer, then horses. And, of course, Christmas. Always Christmas - the lights, the gifts, and above all: the Rockettes. So obsessed with the Rockettes was Abby that every year they’d have to drive into the city to see them perfo-- SMASH! Their car (Abby in backseat) is BLINDSIDED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE - DAY (PRESENT) Will stares ahead, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Her parents died instantly. Abby was trapped in the backseat of the car with them for over an hour until they got her out. Her father... (beat, then) Her father was decapitated by the steering column. A loaded beat.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know, right!? That’s always the detail that gets people. I mean the story in and of itself is tragic, of course, but when you give someone that image - that singular image of a seven year old girl trapped in a car with her decapitated father - then it all really just lands, doesn’t it? (then, chipper) Anyhoo... you asked about Abby so I’1l continue, but be forewarned, her next decade isn’t so great. More SNAPSHOTS from the past. We start with little Abby (fresh off car accident) in a police station.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Abby’s parents didn’t plan on dying together. So there was no will, and no plan for Abby. Seeing as all her grandparents were deceased, Abby’s Uncle Joe was given custody. Uncle Joe wasn’t a nice man. And when I say that, I don’t mean he didn’t hug her. I mean he bought her a puppy and then killed it when it chewed up his couch. I mean he sporadically molested her for the better part of six years until at fifteen years old she borrowed a gun from a wannabe gangbanger at her school, put it to her Uncle Joe's head, and told him in no uncertain terms that... Fifteen-year-old Abby tells her uncle...  33.

dialogues.speaker: FIFTEEN-YEAR-OLD ABBY
dialogues.text: I will fucking kill you if you ever touch me again. She lowers the gun...

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then she shot him in the knee so he knew she wasn’t playing. She does. Uncle Joe howls in pain. INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Will smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Like a movie, right? I always pictured a young Natalie Portman playing her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I don’t know who that is.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You don’t know who Natalie Portman is!? Doc, you gotta get out more.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I’m sure you're right, Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Tell you what, you come over one night, we'll marathon young Natalie Portman: “The Professional,” “Beautiful Girls,” you'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Please continue, Will. Will SHRUGS.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Things got better from there. More SNAPSHOTS from Abby’s past.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Obviously damage had been done. Decapitated father, molesting uncle, you don’t just bounce back from that. But Abby was smart. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Determined. A dreamer. A reader. She hunkered down, got herself into college, started seeing a therapist on campus who truly changed her life, and even made a really close friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG ABBY (20) sits in a library studying. Across a few tables, YOUNG WILL throws candy at her. They starts silently food fighting. Once again, PRESENT DAY WILL steps into frame with Dr. Morris.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Look, Doc, it’s me! This is what I looked like at twenty-one. (then, realizing) Holy shit, my hairline has really receded, hasn't it? He examines his twenty-one-year old self (who, unaware, continues food fighting with Abby).

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look how much lower my hairline was back then. Fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I think you look very much the same.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: And I think I look like a different person.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Tomato-tomahto. Will smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Look at us, Doc, look at us. Maybe we have a chance after all. (then) Anyhow... Will leads Dr. Morris out of the library and through...  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we see college-Abby everywhere... playing intermura soccer, reading on the lawn, making out with Will, etc. Will and Dr. Morris walk through these scenes, one after another.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Abby came into her own in college. She engaged with the world, became extremely popular, even fell in love (not to toot my own horn but toot toot). She graduated top of her class with an English Lit degree, wrote her thesis on...

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Will! will! Suddenly we are in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE FRAT BOY IDIOTS hold Will upside down, readying him chug from a keg. Young Abby rushes over toward Will, nonplussed by the fac that he’s upside down over a keg.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: The unreliable narrator!

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (mile-a-minute) My thesis! Unreliable narrators are considered a “device,” right? Don’t answer, they are. They don’t get a lot of literary analysis because it’s a gimmick, a trick. I mean yeah, Canterbury Tales gets a shout out for having one, but usually it’s the stuff of popcorn crime novels and thriller movies. Agatha Christie, Usual Suspects, so on and so forth. But I’m going to argue that by definition, any narrator is unreliable. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because when someone is telling a story, there is always a distance from the actual story to their telling of the story. Therefore, any story that has EVER been told has an unreliable narrator. The only truly reliable narrator would be someone hypothetically telling a story as it happens before our eyes, which is obviously impossible. And what does that mean? (deep breath) It means that the only truly reliable narrator is life itself. But life itself, by it’s very nature, is an unreliable narrator, too - because it is constantly misdirecting us, misleading us, taking us on a journey where it’s literally impossible to predict what is going to happen next. That’s my thesis: life as the ultimate unreliable narrator. (then) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I think--

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: It’ll make more sense when I write it. Love you! Bye! She races off. Will’s friends stuff the spout back in his mouth as he watches her race off. He’s literally upside-down, in love.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Will sits, lost in thought. He looks up at Dr. Morris.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hey, before, when I invited you over to watch Natalie Portman movies, you know I was just being funny, right?  37.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Because I’m still married. At least I think I am. I haven’t signed any papers or anything yet. Don’t know how this works.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: It’s fine, Will.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Okay. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Tell me about your marriage?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You want me to tell you about my marriage?

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Then you haven’t been listening. It doesn’t matter what I tell you, Doc. His eyes suddenly well with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back where we first saw Will and Abby together, in six months earlier, talking about Bob Dylan.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I could tell you all about our marriage. I could tell you every detail of that morning she left me. We pick up mid-scene (we've seen this already).

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I'm in a phase, Baby. C’mon, lean into this with me. It’s Dylan’s comeback album!  38.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: But is my memory even remotely accurate? We REWIND, play the moment again.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (irritated) I’m in a phase, Will. Why can’t you just lean into this with me? One fucking time, just lean into it with me.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I could tell you how much fun we had together that morning. We've seen this next part, too:

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: He sounds like he has a giant cock lodged in his throat. She playfully smacks him with a pillow.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Asshole! Will rolls on top of her. They wrestle playfully, until..

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, wait, watch Fuckface, are we rolling on Fuckface? Will, careful.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Or... We REWIND, play this part again:

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Will, get off me. Watch Fuckface, are we rolling on Fuckface? (then, urgent)

dialogues.speaker: WILL, GET THE HELL OFF OF ME
dialogues.text: Will gets off her, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Maybe I'd been smothering her for years. Smothering her with my love, with my dreams, with a baby she wasn’t ready for.  39.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHES /SNAPSHOTS
dialogues.text: - Will putting that toy gun to his head. - Will’s parents house filled to the brim with toys. - Abby’s enormous belly. - Fifteen-year-old Abby holding that gun to Uncle Joe’s h

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Maybe I was just another man who looked like he was there to save her life, when he was really just there to ruin it. We SPLIT SCREEN two versions of Abby on that bed, swaying Dylan: In one version, she looks ethereal, happy, contented. In the other, she’s wet eyed, lost in thought, extremely damaged.

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Was she unhappy all along? Was my dream girl just something I'd created in my mind’s eye. A narrative trick, to get us through, you know... a life.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Will sits with Dr. Morris. He takes a sip of his coffee/whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: This is some heavy philosophical shit we're delving into.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: It is, yes. He drinks more. Dr. Morris leans forward. DR. MORRIS (CONT’D) Will, can you talk a little about that day? Will shakes his head “no.” Dr. Morris continues anyways.  40. DR. MORRIS (CONT’D) You had a nice morning with Abby talking about Bob Dylan--

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (fierce) You're not listening, Doc! (then, calming) It may not have been a nice morning. It may have been a smothering morning, that’s what I’m trying to fucking tell you! His outburst is uneven and unnerving. Dr. Morris takes a beat, presses on:

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: And you went to your parents for lunch, and then what happened?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (starting to cry) She just left me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: She didn't just leave you, Will--

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You don’t want me to do this, Doc. Charmingly fucked up Will is a lot more fun than deeply fucked up Will.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Will--

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I‘1ll remind you that deeply fucked up Will has tried to kill himself two times in the past six months.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I’m aware of that--

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I‘1l remind you that the first thing deeply fucked up Will did after he got out from the hospital was buy a gun so he could get it right the third time. Dr. Morris goes silent. This is new information. She nods, leans forward, says gently:  41.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Have you seen Abby since you've been released, Will? Will closes his eyes, remember:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've seen this image before: Will begging Abby to come b to him.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (crying) You know I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Please Abby. Just come back--

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Will? Will looks up (towards her voice):

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I’m talking to my wife!

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: But your wife wasn’t there, was she? We WIDEN... we see Will is sitting at a table by himself. And Will sees it, too. He knows it. He admits:

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No, she wasn’t. Will just stares at the empty seat across from him. He announces to no one in particular:

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not well. I’m very sick.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Dr. Morris leans forward.  42.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: You're not sick, Will. You're sad. You're mixing meds. You're not yourself. (then) Tell me about that morning. We see the previously seen images that Will describes:

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: We talked about Bob Dylan. We laughed. We almost crushed the dog. We went to my parents. We ate meatloaf. He stops. Tears are streaming down his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pregnant Abby and happy Will exit his parents.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Oh my God, I ate too much.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: You ate the gross national meatloaf product of a small nation.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (nodding, sad) We may have a meatloaf instead of a baby. Will LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Walk it off?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Please yes. He takes her hand. They head down the bustling New York C street, slowly, contentedly. After a long beat...

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The baby is a girl, Will. Will turns, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know we weren't going to find out but a nurse slipped up and... I feel shitty knowing without you knowing: (then, nervous excitement) Will, in about three weeks you’re going to have a daughter. Will stands there in stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Say something. Slowly, Will smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Now I get it.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: What!?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I know what you want to name her. 43. Abby smiles mischievously, starts crossing the street. Sh turns back to Will.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I know you don’t like his music but--

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I love it. Abby smiles. It’s a smile that could light up a city bloc And suddenly we hear SCREECHING TIRES. She turns in the direction of the sound. INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Tears stream down Will’s face.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: It’s all I see. Twenty-four hours a day. If I think about something else for one second, it comes back like a wave the next. The bus. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Her face. That singular image of my girl... (gutted) Lying there... just gone. SNAPSHOTS: Like Will’s early screenplay (but this time mercifully avoiding the gore - though we can imagine): - A screeching bus, pandemonium. - Will screaming to back the bus up. - The little Hispanic boy crying inside the bus. Will briefly locks eyes with the boy.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Will, you suffered a horrific, horrific trauma--

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (realizing) I can’t live without her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: You can. For your baby you can. (then) Your baby survived, Will. Miraculously, she lived. Wouldn't Abby want you to be there for your daughter? Will nods, broken. DR. MORRIS (CONT’D) So why haven’t you been to your parents yet? Why haven’t you seen your baby?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Because she was right: I loved her too much. I loved her too hard. All I see is her face. (then, nodding) I'm just done. Will stands, a newfound determination on his face.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Will, please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: If I don’t leave now, I never will.  45.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Will--

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Doc, you're very nice, but I don’t want to be here anymore. I have to do this now or I never will, please close your eyes. (then) I wasn’t the hero of this story. And before we even know what’s happening, Will reaches in his sock, pulls out his gun, puts it in his mouth, and fi It is instantaneous, jarring, and - obviously - shocking. Everything SLOWS and GOES SILENT as Dr. Morris SCREAMS an runs to Will... then out the door (screaming). CUE SONG: The most populist track from Bob Dylan’s Time O of Mind album: To Make Me Feel Your Love. A long beat, as we process this... then: A new “narrator” takes over, this time A LITTLE GIRL:

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dear Rod. I got your letter and it was very nice. You spell really good my Nana says, and you seem like a very nice boy she says too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little girl’s hand writes this letter, carefully.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think you are lucky that you have a bird. I have a dog. He is my best friend. Do you like pizza? I Mainly like pizza and dogs. But dogs more. Reveal: A LITTLE GIRL (6). Adorable. Wise beyond her handful of years. LITTLE GIRL (CONT’D) (as she writes) From, Dylan Dempsey. This is Will and Abby’s daughter, aged six years.  46. Our earlier FEMALE ADULT NARRATOR takes back over.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: To say Dylan Dempsey’s childhood was marked by death and tragedy would be the grossest of understatements... and also a little bit douchey. TIGHT ON SIX-YEAR-OLD DYLAN’S face. She looks directly in lens.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She was literally born of death and tragedy. SCREECH! The sound of a bus. Little Dylan flinches.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Six months into her little life, her father started locking in the pattern. GUNSHOT! Dylan flinches again.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And this was all before the poor kid even understood what the hell was going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIX-MONTH-OLD DYLAN plays on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND HER
dialogues.text: Slightly out of focus, her grandparents are hysterically crying and holding each other. Baby Dylan watches them, as if understanding.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The fallout from Will Dempsey’s suicide was instant, long lasting, and far reaching. INT. NEW YORK APARTMENT -— EVENING Dr. Morris sits on the couch, wrapped in a blanket, dazed teary. Her HUSBAND rubs her back, but she just stares forward at  47.

dialogues.speaker: A TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: She's watching young Natalie Portman in “The Professional INT. DYLAN’S NEW HOME - CONTINUOUS Baby Dylan watches her grandparents cry. Little Fuckface (the dog) comes over and licks her face.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dylan would now be raised by her mid-sixties grandparents, Irwin and Linda. And the odds weren’t great that they’d last very long.

dialogues.speaker: ON IRWIN
dialogues.text: He sits on the couch, stares into lens, crying. As our narrator describes his condition - arrows, stats, graphics demonstrate what she describes:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Irwin Dempsey was sixty-six years old. He was 5'10” and he weighed 265 pounds. When people would caution that you don’t see a lot of nearly 300 pound, 70 year olds walking around, Irwin would always say:

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: (proud but sad) You will soon, Mother Fucker.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Irwin had high cholesterol, severe arthritis, and the beginnings of gout. And he was the healthiest of Dylan’s new caretakers. The camera swings over to Linda Dempsey, who now stares directly into lens, crying.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For two decades, Linda Dempsey had managed her clinical anxiety and depression with a ever-evolving cocktail of Prozac, Zoloft, and white wine. Linda nods into lens, teary.  48.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that anxiety and depression did not even account for her only child's suicide, nor the grapefruit sized tumor which she had no idea was growing inside of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irwin stands at Linda’s grave with now EIGHT-YEAR-OLD DYL She looks up at her grandfather, sees that he’s crying. She takes his hand. INT. DYLAN’S BEDROOM - EVENING Dylan sits in bed with an aging Fuckface. Around her room we get a sense of the girl... - A writing DESK. - Little girl pinks and purples, mixed - strangely - with DYLAN POSTERS. - A PHOTOGRAPH of Abby, Will, and a much younger Fuckface happier/earlier times. It is almost viscerally painful. KNOCK KNOCK. Irwin stands at the half open door. He’s holding a glass whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: How you feeling, Kiddo? She SHRUGS.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I feel like my whole life is going to be marked by death and tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She did not say this, of course, but if she could verbalize what she was feeling at eight years old, she would have. Irwin sits next to her. Eight-year-old “Dylan” continues expressing her innermost thoughts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I crave a happy life, Grandpa. I have an almost desperate craving for stability and happiness, the way fat people crave chocolate or lost hikers crave rescue. I want to live a big great fantastical life. But I’m concerned that the tragedy that seems to follow me - the tragedy that birthed me - will prevent that from ever happening. And I don’t know if I can withstand another body blow like this.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But what she really said was:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Are you gonna die, Grandpa? Irwin takes a sip of his whiskey, thinks. Then:

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: Yes. I am. And probably sooner than you'd like, Kiddo, if I’m being honest. But I’m gonna fight like hell to stick around for you as long as possible, to prevent one more death from coming anywhere near your doorstep. I’m gonna get on the fucking treadmill, I’m gonna cut back on the red meat, I’m gonna do my best to get you through your teenage years without losing one more goddamn thing. He nods, determined. IRWIN (CONT’D) I’m going to do that for your mother and father. I’m going to do it for your grandmother. But mostly I’m going to do it for you, Granddaughter. He looks at her, eyes welling with tears and love. IRWIN (CONT’D) Yeah, I’m going to squeeze out ten more years from this decrepit old body for you, my girl. My angel. My world.  50.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Again: Irwin expressed this all with:

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: Nah, no more dying around here, Kiddo. Okay? Irwin holds out his whiskey to toast his granddaughter. She pretends to hold a glass of her own, and “clinks” wit him. They take a real/fake sip together, and at the same time:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN/ IRWIN
dialogues.text: (re: real/fake whiskey) Ahhhhhh.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But Irwin had no more power to prevent loss than any of us do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NINE-YEAR-OLD Dylan sits on the floor. Next to her, Fuckface lies on his side - dying. She pets him, gently. BEHIND HER, Irwin stands with a VET. He slams his hand into the wall in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Vet injects Fuckface, putting him down. Dylan keeps petting the dog, locking eyes with him.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Tell them I’m nice. She places that long-ago PHOTOGRAPH of her parents and Fuckface next to dog. It will be buried with him.  51. INT. DYLAN’S BEDROOM - LATER Dylan comes home, begins tearing the Bob Dylan posters of her wall.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Her mother gets hit by a bus. Her father commits suicide. Her grandmother dies of cancer. (then) But it was the death of a mini goldendoodle that ended Dylan Dempsey’s childhood. Dylan turns, looks into lens again. As she does, and as our narrator continues, Dylan slowly ever so slowly - MORPHS in front of our eyes from an INNO NINE-YEAR-OLD GIRL to a TEENAGER.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: 2025 to 2033: the Dylan Dempsey Transformation Years. The years brought puberty. Puberty brought sexuality. Sexuality brought anger. And fear. And confusion. And when the smoke cleared - where that sweet little girl once stood - there remained only a teenager who scared the absolute shit out of everyone. Dylan turns back to lens, revealing a fully evolved 18-YE OLD DYLAN DEMPSEY. She is a knockout, in a dangerous, way-too-sexy way. She begins throwing stuff in a BACKPACK. KNOCK KNOCK. Irwin stands at the door again, aged ten years himself. H thinner. Older. He may have cut out that red meat, but not the whiskey. He’s holding his ubiquitous glass of it.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: Hey. She doesn’t even turn around.  She grabs He shrugs A beat. 52.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I’m heading out.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: With who? a pack of cigarettes from a drawer. IRWIN (CONT’D) You're not even going to try and hide those from me?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Aren’t we both better than that? in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: (re: cigarettes) You hear Vermont’s made them illegal?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Remind me never to go to Vermont.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: ("little boy”) Can I have one?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: Just one?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: No, these things will kill you. She pops a cigarette in her mouth. Irwin cringes at the sight.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: I was hoping we could talk about college.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: We talked about it last night.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: We didn’t get very far.  53.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Yes we did. We just didn’t get where you wanted. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: Promise to be home by eleven?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I'd rather not lie to you.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: Lie to me.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I’1l be home by eleven. She walks past him. He grabs her arm, turns her.

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN
dialogues.text: Dylan. He looks at her. He looks old, tired. She softens, ever so slightly. IRWIN (CONT’D) Happy eighteenth, Kiddo. He holds out his whiskey glass, as he once did to that adorable little girl. She rolls her eyes, but - after a moment - gives in and CLINKS an imaginary glass against his. At the same time, they both sip and...

dialogues.speaker: IRWIN/DYLAN
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhh. Irwin touches her cheek. And suddenly we see it: sweet innocent Dylan is still in there, somewhere... Then she takes Irwin’s real whiskey glass and downs it in gulp.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Peace. She winks, EXITS.  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dylan sits in the backseat of a small SUV. THREE YOUNG MEN (two up front, one in back) sit in the ca with them. Everyone is smoking. In the back of the SUV we see music equipment (instrument amps, etc.). It is important to remember: it is 2033 now. All around u we notice the changes in costume, in vehicles, in technol Not a paradigm shift by any means - no flying cars - but all part of the landscape.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: So I say to her - your friend looks lonely. Why don’t the three of us get to know one another-- As the other bandmates “male bond,” Dylan looks out the window of the car.

dialogues.speaker: ON STREET
dialogues.text: They are passing the very intersection where Dylan’s moth Abby - exactly eighteen years earlier - was struck by tha bus.

dialogues.speaker: ON DYLAN
dialogues.text: As the car comes to a stop at a traffic light. Right at t spot. Dylan lowers the window and sticks her head (and her enti top half of her body, really) out of the car. She hovers over the very spot where her mother died. As the light turns green, Dylan flicks her cigarette out window... Onto that exact spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dylan is mid-performance, the lead singer for the band. SIGNAGE announces her band’s name: PB&J.  55. Note: their music is the popular underground music of 203 violent, electronica-based form of rock ‘n’ roll. Watching Dylan screaming and flailing on stage is jarring say the least. But she’s also a star performer. Captivating. Raw. The most damaged people always make for our greatest arti The song finishes. The sparse audience CHEERS. Dylan grabs a MUG OF BEER from a nearby ledge and quietly speaks to the crowd, commanding their attention:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Our last song is kinda personal. My mom died eighteen years ago today, and--

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK
dialogues.text: Take it off!

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (explosive)

dialogues.speaker: FUCK YOU
dialogues.text: Dylan calms herself, takes a sip of her beer, continues:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They tell me she used to listen to--

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK
dialogues.text: Show us your tits!!! Dylan THROWS her mug out at the kid. It shatters in the distance. Dylan gives up on “context,” simply announces:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: This is our last song. Dylan steps over toward a nearby keyboard, begins playing Softly she starts singing, beautifully. It’s To Make You Feel My Love by Bob Dylan... unplugged.  56.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (singing) When the rain is blowing in your face/and the whole world is on your case/I could offer you a warm embrace/to make you feel my love... And with that: The band explodes. Suddenly this becomes a violent/thrashing version of the commercial love song on Bob Dylan’s otherwise perfectly b album. Dylan is simply on fire: screaming, stalking the stage, letting out as many of the ghosts that haunt her as possi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dylan gives a blowjob to the drummer of the band. If it was hard to watch Will and Abby’s only daughter smo cigarettes, this is worse. Way worse. Adding to the horror, is the fact that HANGERS-ON and oth band members are watching this. Laughing. Pointing. A NEARBY GIRL is even video-ing the oral sex on her phone Finally Dylan stands, the act completed. Without missing a beat she grabs the phone from the video taping girl and SMASHES it. And like that... Dylan calmly heads to a nearby card table and grabs herse SANDWICH from a pile of PB&J sandwiches (the band’s fuel, namesake). She’s about to leave, when:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You owe me a new phone, Bitch. Dylan looks up. It’s the girl whose phone she just smashe  57.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (apologetic) You're right. I’m sorry, I shouldn’t have done that. It’s just been a weird day for me and I got heated. She reaches toward her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, let me see what I have on me-- Without warning, Dylan attacks the girl. It’s brutal - and admittedly strange - to watch a pretty eighteen-year-old girl get so violent and so feral, so quickly. Dylan takes the other girl down and pins her. She starts pummeling her.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think that’s funny, taping me? You're not laughing now are you, Bitch!? Punch. Slap. Punch. Dylan smushes that PB&J sandwich into the girl’s face, violently. Finally Dylan is pulled off of the traumatized and bloody victim. Dylan shakes off her “referees,” grabs a fresh sandwich, EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dylan walks back to that street corner where her mother d It’s late, very few cars. Dylan looks out at the quiet street. She lights a joint. Smokes it. She takes a bite of her fresh sandwich. Chews. She takes another hit from the joint. And then... DYLAN’S POV  58. As she sees her mother and father, at that same street corner, eighteen years earlier to the day: It’s the scene we’ve seen before, but now their daughter (back then unborn, but now eighteen) is there, too.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: .-. Will, in about three weeks you’re going to have a daughter.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (top of her lungs) NO HE’S NOT!!!! FUCKER’S GONNA

dialogues.speaker: MEETING ME
dialogues.text: But, of course, Will and Abby can’t hear her.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Say something. Slowly, Will smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Now I get it.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: What !?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: YOU DON’T GET IT, ASSHOLE! YOU

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I know what you want to name her. Abby smiles mischievously, starts crossing the street. Sh turns back to Will.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I know you don’t like his music but--

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: I love it. Abby smiles.  59.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (sing-songy )

dialogues.speaker: HERE COMES THE BUSSSSS
dialogues.text: But suddenly a desperation takes over for Dylan.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom, look out. (then) Mom? MOM!!! LOOK OUT! And suddenly we hear SCREECHING TIRES. Dylan closes her eyes (she can’t watch). When she opens them, the street is empty once more. She recovers, takes a bite of her sandwich. She breathes deeply, looks back up. BUT NOW, IN FRONT OF HER... The bus is back (or at least the memory of it). Pressed up against the glass, inside the bus, is that lit four-year-old Hispanic boy. His eyes are welling with tears. Dylan’s eyes are, too. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOY
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Does it matter? She takes a bite of her sandwich. On the bus, the little boy cocks his head, taking her in.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If four-year-old Rodrigo Gonzales had really been there that night, he might have told the stoned young woman standing in front of him that it mattered quite a bit to him that Dylan Dempsey was okay.  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Rodrigo sits with his mother and father in the bac a New York City bus. Rodrigo is adorable, carefree, and curious. He’s holding a plastic Statue of Liberty toy souvenir and wearing an “I LOVE NEW YORK” T-shirt. His blue-collar parents JAVIER (big smile, barrel-chested and ISABEL (beautifully tired, stoic) wear similar T-shir They are fighting a losing battle to control their rambunctious son. But they don’t seem to mind losing the battle. This family enjoys one another. They love, openly. Important note to reader: all conversation within this st will be in Spanish, and subtitled).

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: I want to go up front.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Sit, Hijo.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Oh, c’mon, Mamasita, let the boy explore.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: (amused smile) And are you going to walk him up and down the aisle?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: (playful teasing) As a matter of fact I am. Isabel rolls her eyes as Javier takes Rodrigo’s hand. We follow little Rodrigo down the aisle as he somehow man to draw smiles from even this jaded New York commuter cro

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: Hola... Hola... Hola...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Before their trip to New York City, the Gonzales family had never ventured outside of Spain. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Andulucia region, to be more specific. Rodrigo stops toward the middle of the bus as a man entertains him with a magic trick (coin in the ear).

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They were simple, happy people, from a simple, happy place. Vacations did not come naturally to them - frankly, it never occurred to them that they might need a break from anything. A coin gets pulled from a euphoric Rodrigo’s ear. Javier LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But little Rodrigo had become obsessed with New York City. So his loving father bought cheap plane fares and booked the most rat- infested Manhattan hotel imaginable. (then) Until this moment, it had been the trip of a lifetime. Javier gets drawn into conversation (in Spanish) with a nearby older woman as little Rodrigo keeps moving down th aisle.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Again: simple people, with their own simple, unique, brand of happiness. Javier looks back at his wife, winks at her. Isabel smiles back, motions for him to keep an eye on Rod (who has run up toward the bus driver).

dialogues.speaker: ON RODRIGO
dialogues.text: Approaching the driver.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: Hola.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: (few steps behind) Hijo, leave him.  62.

dialogues.speaker: BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: (looking down momentarily) No, it’s oka-- Someone SCREAMS. The bus driver looks back up and SLAMS O THE BREAKS. Rodrigo and Javier (the only ones standing) go flying. Pandemonium. We’ve seen this all but from the outside perspective. Now we’re inside the bus seeing: Spectators SCREAMING. Will Dempsey, outside, FRANTICALLY YELLING for the bus to back up. The BUS DRIVER doing so. Little Rodrigo rising to his feet, unhurt, and seeing wha beneath the bus (we don’t). RODRIGO’S POV: His little body blocks our view of the horrifying carnage All we see is Abby Dempsey’s unharmed, enormously pregnan belly. And, of course, we see Will Dempsey. Rodrigo locks eyes with Will. His little eyes fill with tears just as... Javier (forehead bleeding) scoops Rodrigo up and carries away from the window. As Javier carries Rodrigo back to his frantic mother, checking for injuries, everything SLOWS. CUE SONG: A Spanish version of Not Dark Yet by Bob Dylan. Through the following, we stay with traumatized Rodrigo (staring back at the scene of the crime).

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The lives of two families were forever changed that day. The Dempseys were, as we know, shattered - instantly and in full. But for the Gonzales family, it would take some time for the effects of the accident to fully take root. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (then) And theirs was a family that knew quite a bit about roots. We hear HAPPY WHISTLING and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LABORER’S ROUGH HANDS feel the earth around an OLIVE TR ROOTS, checking on dampness of the soil. The hands pick up fallen OLIVES from the ground, check fo bruises.

dialogues.speaker: THE SAME HANDS
dialogues.text: As they ever so gently slide olives off a small branch an into a bucket (brucatura).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revealing that the hands belong to a younger Javier (Rodrigo’s father). He’s about ten years younger here. There’s something beautiful about this big, barrel-cheste young man so gently caring for these olives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revealing a 200-ACRE OLIVE GROVE. It’s harvest time, and all around Javier, OTHER LABORERS olives from other trees. The other laborers use an easier, and more common “by han technique. What they are doing is called “a mano con telo or, simply, “by hand with net.” In a nutshell: they have placed LARGE NETS around the tru of the trees, and use a combination of RAKES and LADDERS loosen the olives en masse (which then fall into the nets But Javier just sits up high, WHISTLING, sliding those ol into his bucket by hand - olive after olive. A FANCY PICKUP approaches and a laborer calls out:  64.

dialogues.speaker: LABORER
dialogues.text: He’s here. MURMURS and CHEERS as everyone races toward the truck. AN ELEGANT MAN (40s) steps out and greets his workers. This is MR. SACCIONE. He’s Italian, dapper, and otherworl handsome. And these guys fucking love him. As he greets each man by name, and shakes their hands, he looks off in the distance...

dialogues.speaker: TO JAVIER
dialogues.text: The only man still working. Sitting atop his ladder, slid olives into his bucket, contentedly. The boss may have arrived, but for Javier nothing has changed. Though he has stopped whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stunning Spanish farmhouse. Views as far as the eye can see. Mr. Saccione sits at a desk, writing. Behind him, young Javier steps into the room. He’s dirty from work and clearly uncomfortable standing before his b He debates how to announce his presence when...

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Javier, thank you for coming down. Mr. Saccione turns. MR. SACCIONE (CONT’D) Come, sit. Sit. Mr. Saccione motions at an armchair. MR. SACCIONE (CONT’D) Drink?  65. Javier shakes his head no. Mr. Saccione sits on the couch opposite him. MR. SACCIONE (CONT’D) It occurs to me that we’ve never really spoken. Five years I’ve owned this land, Javier, and I don’t think we’ve said more than a few words to one another. Javier shifts uncomfortably. MR. SACCIONE (CONT’D) I was raised in Italy, you know this, yes? That I’m Italian? Aha, yes, you know. But do you know that I’m only half-Italian? This is true, Javier! My Italian father traveled to Andulucia as a young man and this is where he met my mother - did you know any of this? Did you know my mother was from the area?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: No, Senor.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: A royal fuck of a man, my father. Few men have ever been worse, of this I am certain, Javier. He met my young mother, swept her off her feet, then moved her away from everything she knew and everyone she loved. He was possessive and controlling and abusive. And he was rich, which makes a royal fuck of a man like that particularly dangerous-- are you sure I can’t offer you a drink? Wine, tequila, anything you want?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: (tentative) Cervesa?

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Yes, of course! Cervesa! Mr. Saccione hops to his feet, continues his story from t next room:  66. MR. SACCIONE (CONT’D) (yelling back) So there’s my young mother - a full blooded Spanish Andulucian cut off from her family, living in the Italian countryside - doesn’t speak a word of Italian by the way-- it’s a little warm, I’m sorry. He’s returned, hands Javier the beer. He sits back down. MR. SACCIONE (CONT’D) My father decides he wants an “Italian” wife. An “Italian” family. So he disallows Spanish in his home. He cuts off contact with her family. Mama has nothing to care about. No one to love. And so... she gets pregnant. With me. As I get older, we make a pact: she will teach me Spanish, she will teach me about that half of my heritage - but my father must never know. And over those years -— whenever my father travels for work - she secretly arranges for packages to be shipped from her homeland. Spanish foods and wines and treats - we would eat them so fast our stomach would swell, Javier! Always making sure we never left a trace that my father might discover. Our favorite treat was always the Spanish olive oil. Can you imagine, Javier!? There we are in the Italian countryside - home to the richest olive oil in the world - pouring Spanish olive oil down our throats like you and I now drink this cervesa. What a pair Mama and I were. What a pair indeed. Mr. Saccione sips his beer. MR. SACCIONE (CONT’D) She died, my mother. When I was just sixteen. As soon as she died, that royal fuck of a man cut me off. I lived in squalor through my teens and twenties. He saw my mother in me, Javier. And in my mother he saw only a dirty Spaniard who had ruined his life.  67. A beat. Slowly, Mr. Saccione smiles. MR. SACCIONE (CONT’D) Luckily for me: my father wasn’t just a bigot, he was also a narcissist. He never thought he would die, even as he got older, even as he got sicker. And so... he never made a will. (then) The moment that royal fuck of a man left this earth, I became a wildly wealthy man, Javier. And the first thing I did was buy this land back in Andulucia, where I now grow hundreds of acres of the olive oil that Mama and I once hoarded. And while business keeps me away most of the time, this land is the only thing that matters to me, Javier. This land is my story, and it is my mama’s story. It is everything to me. This hangs there.
