Mr. Saccione finishes off his beer. MR. SACCIONE (CONT’D) And so, Javier: that is why the olives mean so much to me. And now I must ask you: why do they mean so much to you?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I do not follow.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: The other men use nets and rakes, you pick by hand. You can only pick half as many--

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: (defensive) I work twice as long.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: No, I am aware. This is not criticism, Javier. It is simply a question. Why do you work harder then the other men?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Because it’s the right way--  68.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: (exploding) Jesus, Javier, come on! He quickly calms himself a little.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tell you my story. I tell you the story of my fuck of a father and my poor abused mother... and when I ask you for the same all I get is “because it’s the right way?” (then, jovial again) Come now, Javier! Drink your cervesa! Tell me your story! Javier thinks, puts down his beer.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I am a simple man. I do not have a story. I did not have a fuck of a father. My father was funny and whistled why he worked, and I like having a job where I can whistle while I work, too. The rakes bruise the olives so I pick them by hand. It’s the right way. That is all. Mr. Saccione goes quiet.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Do you have a family?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I have a woman. I hope to make her my wife.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Will you have children?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I believe so, yes. One day.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: The men love you. I hear you telling them stories, making them laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I have a big mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: But with me, you are reserved.  69.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: You are my boss.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: I wish to be your friend. Javier shakes his head. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: No. I would disappoint you as your friend.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: I disagre--

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I have given my answer.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: The other men admire me, and they barely know me. But you - you hear my story and it does not affect you. It does not make you like me. (beat) It’s okay, you can be honest. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: No. It does not.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: May I ask why--

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I would not have taken his money. A simple answer, from a simple man. But it says everything. Loaded silence. Mr. Saccione nods, stands. He pours himself a tequila.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Would you like to live here and oversee the men, Javier? As Senorito? You and your future wife and future children could live on the property.  70.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: For free?

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Yes, of course there would be a raise--

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: No. My salary is fair. The free rent would be helpful enough. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have one condition.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: (smiling) You have a condition for getting a raise?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I will take care of your land. I will help it thrive and I will treat it as my own. But my whistling is for me, and my big mouth is for the men. You will not ask of that from me ever again. (then) In turn, I will be the one man here to never ask anything of you. As Mr. Saccione considers this...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At exactly this moment, a mere 4000 miles away, Abby Dempsey (then Abby Lesher) had just finished the first draft of her college thesis...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. WILL’S COLLEGE BEDROOM - DAY Will sits on his bed. Abby stands in front of him, readin him her paper. It’s surreal to see them again.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (reading) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: but life itself proves to be the most unreliable of narrators - forever taking us on a journey where it is impossible to predict what might happen next. (breaking from reading) Okay, this next part might be too flowery---

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Read, Woman!

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I just worry that it’s not even literary criticism anymo--

dialogues.speaker: READ
dialogues.text: Abby breathes deep, continues:

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Life itself tricks us, it misleads us, it paints one man a hero when he may well be a villain. BACK ON: MR. SACCIONE.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hero or villain? BACK ON: JAVIER.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Villain or hero? WIDEN, as the two men sip their cervesas in silence.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Or maybe neither. Maybe life is playing the role of unreliable trickster, yet again. Maybe those it paints as the heroes and villains of our stories are actually just day players in a much bigger movie. BACK TO ABBY AND WILL.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe they are simply extras, filling the frame, just so the real heroes can have bodies crossing in the background.  Abby finishes reading, looks sheepishly up at Will. A long beat of silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Holy shit, you’re so much smarter than me.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I really am, aren’t I? 72. Will grabs her as she GIGGLES and they start messing arou As we watch these two ill-fated college kids begin to mak the kind of jubilant love only ill-fated college age kids make...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Abby’s thesis was a total disaster. Her favorite and most trusted professor argued - as she feared he might - that she had strayed from literary criticism and had veered into an unwieldy cross of creative writing and seventeenth century French philosophy. He said Abby had essentially regurgitated the philosopher Descartes who in his Third and Fifth Meditations discarded perception as unreliable - which, Abby’s favorite and most trusted professor argued, was all Abby was really saying herself. (then) Then Abby's favorite and most trusted professor tried to fuck her... which, one might argue, proved Abby’s thesis after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier skips through the town square, WHISTLING as always He holds a rose.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A continent away, Javier Gonzales was worried about none of this. Javier Gonzales didn’t philosophize and he never wondered what life had in store for him. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Javier Gonzales knew where he was going. He’d known all along. Javier stops in front of a SMALL THEATRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full-on traditional Flamenco show is in motion. All eyes in the crowd are on a STUNNING WOMAN (20s), in f Flamenco gear, gracefully and powerfully commanding the stage. Yes, all eyes are on her... except for Javier's. He is the one person (in the entire room) looking in the complete opposite direction at... A WAITRESS (who we recognize as Rodrigo’s future mother, ISABEL) . She looks tired. Her dress is prematurely old and worn, l her. She looks up. She locks eyes with Javier. He beams and holds up his rose. She beams back. Sometimes it’s that simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier sits outside by a fountain, holding his rose, wait Isabel EXITS the theatre, looks around for him. For a moment, Javier just watches her eyes search. This i clearly one of his favorite hobbies, watching Isabel sear for him and catching her at the exact moment when she spo him. Which happens right... now. She beams. He beams back.  74.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Isabel Diaz had been taught from birth to expect a very average life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a composed lineup of SIX YOUNG GIRLS. The camera pans the line, left to right, starting with th

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She was one of six sisters, and was openly considered to be the fourth prettiest. We stop panning four girls down the line, on ISABEL. Here she’s 7, and ordinary. We push in on her blank littl face.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: By the same debilitating rating system, Isabel was considered the third smartest, and fourth funniest of the sisters. She’d been born average, something hammered home by even her favorite relative: her abuela. REVEAL: Abuela (70) in Isabel’s face.

dialogues.speaker: ABUELA
dialogues.text: You are not special like some of your sisters, but you’re not useless like the others. You are in the middle. Maybe you can be a waitress or a teacher one day. Try not to get too fat and maybe you can even meet a man and have someone to share meals with for the rest of your life. Little Isabel nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. THEATRE —- CONTINUOUS Isabel, smiling, approaches Javier.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Isabel's very average life had played out in the very average fashion that everyone had forecasted for her. (then) Until Javier came along. She arrives at Javier. He hands her the rose.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: You were amazing tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Amazing, you say? I was amazing serving tapas and having my ass grabbed by drunks?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: The best I’ve ever seen. She LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Javier had worked hard to undo Isabel's programming. Slowly, he believed, she was starting to see that she was special enough to deserve a special life, even if it was to be a simple one.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We push (high speed) through olive trees until we land on A group of shelters and sheds known, collectively, as a CORTIJO. These are the structures on a farm (finca) which house laborers, livestock, mills, etc. The largest building is a two-story structure, the reside for a SENORITO (Javier's new position). He now stands in front of this charming two-story home, showing it off to Isabel:  76.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: (stunned) You will live here? All of this is yours?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: No, Bonita. Ours. I would like it to be ours. She looks at him, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can make a life for us now. I will not be a rich man, but I will be a good one. TI have devoted myself to you since the moment I first saw you, but now I would like to make it official. Isabel--

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Javier stops.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I answer yes. Yes to everything. Javier smiles, grabs her. CUE: a CANTE JONDO SONG. Cante Jondo translates as “deep song” - a weighty style of Andulucian Flamenco. It’s basically the Flamenco blues. There is a staccato vocal driving the song that feels lik euphoric celebration one moment, desperate sadness the ne It feels like life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier and Isabel dance. As they do, the camera circles them - leaving one of them picking up the other, over and over again. As the camera circles... years pass. Facial hair changes for Javier each time we return to him Hairstyles for Isabel each time we return to her. Eventually, Isabel becomes pregnant.  77. They keep dancing, her belly growing larger and larger. Eventually, there’s a baby held between them (little Rodrigo). As we continue to circle, and they continue to dance, Rod grows to four years old (the age we first met him at). Throughout this (from outside the large bay window behind them), we sometimes catch MR. SACCIONE, watching them dan Usually he looks on with a smile, happy for the sweet you lovers. But occasionally, there’s a glint of something different his eye. Is it jealousy? Is he coveting Isabel? Their love? Their new son? It’s probably nothing. But if it’s nothing, why does the Flamenco music always s a little more ominous when the camera finds him?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. JAVIER & ISABEL’S HOME - MORNING Isabel makes coffee on a small wood-burning stove. She looks towards the small kitchen table where: Mr. Saccione plays with little Rodrigo (4). He’s brought Rodrigo a beautiful GLOBE.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: .-. and over there, Javier, that is America.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: New York?

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Yes, New York, you remember this!? (to Isabel) What a child this is! He remembers my story of traveling to New York from weeks ago, and now connects it to the proper country! Isabel smiles, delivers the coffee.  78.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: He remembers everything you teach him.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Isabel could no longer remember when Mr. Saccione first started coming over to visit Rodrigo. ON MR. SACCIONE and RODRIGO, bonding. Isabel watches.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She only knew that the visits had become more consistent. Usually in the middle of the day, always when Javier was in the fields.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: In English, Rodrigo, Nueva York is “New York,” can you say this? New York?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: New York.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: What a child! In perfect imitation of the accent no less! I just love this child! Isabel flinches, slightly uncomfortable with that sentime coming from him. Mr. Saccione notices, goes quiet.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Isabel liked Mr. Saccione. She liked the things he exposed Rodrigo to - a breadth of knowledge and experience that she and Javier could never access. So while she had never hidden Mr. Saccione’s visits from her husband, it was fair to say she'd undersold their frequency and intensity. Mr. Saccione stands, approaches Isabel.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: I apologize. I overstay my welcome--

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. I have many great things in my life, Mrs. Gonzales, but I fear my strange upbringing has left me with such scars... I have been unable to find the greatest of things. It is not fair for me to try and fill that void here. He’s close to Isabel. It’s a bit intimate, quiet.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Don’t be silly. We enjoy having you. Rodrigo loves you.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: This is kind of you to say. He is truly such a special boy. Oh the things I might teach him one day! English and literature and--

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Saccione. Isabel and Mr. Saccione whirl. Javier stands in the doorw

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Ah, Javier, good, I came to talk to you about the extension to the mill and brought a gift for your son--

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Thank you, but my son has enough toys. Javier takes the globe away from Rodrigo.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: (crying) No!

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Javier. Javier shoots her a look, silencing her, and hands Mr. Saccione back the globe.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: It is too generous, Jefe. Now come, let me fill you in on the status of the mill. (pointedly) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And from here forth, when you need me, you can just send word. I will come to you and save you the trip.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: (getting it) Of course. Mr. Saccione tips his cap toward Isabel and Rodrigo.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: (through tears) I want to go to New York with him! As Javier escorts Mr. Saccione out of his home, he looks at his wife. She looks equal parts furious (at Javier) and ashamed (of herself).

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Javier Gonzales was a simple man, but not a stupid one. And that day, he began doing something he'd never done before: planning a family vacation. To a place that - he’d just learned - his son desperately wanted to visit with someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In FLASHES, we watch the Gonzales family enjoy their New City vacation: - They walk the streets of Manhattan. Rambunctious Rodrig points out everything, enamored with the scope of the cit - The family sleeps (all in one bed) in a cramped youth hostile. They are surrounded by backpackers and vagrants. But they sleep contentedly, happy as can be. A true famil - They take in the Statue of Liberty. - They buy crappy “I love NYC” T-shirts. - They sit in the back of a bus, wearing their new T-shir (we’ve seen this already). - Javier chases rambunctious Rodrigo down the aisle of th bus (we’ve seen this, too).  81. - Javier (bloody) carries Rodrigo away from the front of bus, post accident.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A pregnant woman eviscerated by a bus. A grown man weeping, desperately. Bystanders screaming. It was only about twenty seconds of footage but it would replay on a loop in little Rodrigo Gonzales’s brain for years to come.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. RODRIGO’S BEDROOM (SPAIN) - NIGHT Little Rodrigo tosses and turns in bed. He SCREAMS, waking himself. He has wet the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. RODRIGO’S BEDROOM - LATER Isabel tries to calm her sweaty child, a cold compress on head. Javier watches from the doorway. He shifts, unsure what t do. Everything that makes Javier Gonzales great elsewhere, ma him ill equipped here.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was textbook early childhood trauma... and it was happening to a family without any textbooks. INT. JAVIER & ISABEL’S HOME - DAY Rodrigo (now 5) throws a tantrum as Isabel tries to get h to eat. Javier ENTERS, closing the door behind him. The door slamming makes Rodrigo jump. Javier and Isabel share a look.  82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier and Isabel fight. Angrily. The stress of their unwell child is taking a toll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo (now 6) gets in a fight on the playground with another LITTLE BOY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier and Isabel fight again. In a heated moment, Javier punches the wall next to Isabel’s head. He recoils at himself. She runs off. He grabs a BOTTLE and starts drinking. INT. RODRIGO’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Rodrigo, in bed, SCREAMS again... startling himself awake He has wet the bed, per usual. INT. JAVIER & ISABEL 'S BEDROOM — CONTINUOUS Isabel and Javier lie in bed. They hear Rodrigo’s SCREAM from the next room and Isabel STANDS to go to him. Clearly this has become routine. She stops at the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: He is not getting better, Javier.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I know. This hangs there.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: He doesn’t talk about it. I try but... he can’t. Or he won’t.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: It was just one moment. How can one moment just... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then, convincing himself) He was so little. Soon he’1l forget. Yes, he will get better, Bonita. I know this. But Javier's eyes betray him.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: We need to get him help.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: We took him to all the doctors--

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: He needs specialists. In Madrid. The doctors the rich people would go to.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: We are not rich people. Isabel looks at Javier. He suddenly gets what she’s askin

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: He is our son, Javier. He is our little boy and he is in pain. Javier looks at his beautiful wife. She’s pleading with h eyes. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: If you want, I will ask hi--

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: (sharply) No. (then, loving) No, Bonita. I must. INT. MR. SACCIONE’S FARMHOUSE - MORNING Mr. Saccione sits at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Sir? Mr. Saccione looks up in surprise. As Javier begins to speak, uncomfortable...  84.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The things we do for our children are often the worst things we do to ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo works in a room with a THERAPIST. He draws pictur plays with toys, etc. ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE VIEWING WINDOW: Mr. Saccione, Isabel, and Javier watch.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Money cannot buy happiness. Good health, however, is sometimes very much for sale. And Mr. Saccione spared no expense when it came to helping little Rodrigo Gonzales.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE - LATER The Therapist talks to Mr. Saccione and Isabel. Javier is there, of course, but his body language indicat that he’s become a mere support figure.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The diagnosis was, as expected, textbook: clinical early childhood trauma at an age when Rodrigo’s still developing brain had been particularly at risk. The Therapist continues talking. Mr. Saccione asks the bu of the questions. Javier blinks, trying to understand.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It would take time, but it was treatable. In therapist speak, Rodrigo would need to learn to create a coherent narrative about what happened that day. Being able to tell the story of the event would help him master his feelings. And one day there might be a breakthrough, a moment when Rodrigo could fully accept what had happened to him and begin to move forward.  85. Mr. Saccione takes notes. Javier watches, completely out his depth. A spectator in his own son’s life. INT. JAVIER & ISABEL’S HOME - MORNING Mr. Saccione gives Rodrigo a BIRD as a gift (red ribbon o the cage). Isabel and Javier watch.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Months passed. Mr. Saccione’s visits were no longer restricted, his gifts no longer withheld. Javier knew he’d opened the floodgates... he just hadn't realized how much water he was letting in. Javier leaves the room. No one notices. INT. THERAPIST’S OFFICE - DAY Rodrigo (now 7) draws a picture of a the SCENE OF THE ACCIDENT. Front and center is a woman (Abby) on the groun with a huge, pregnant belly.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rodrigo started improving. INT. RODRIGO’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Rodrigo (almost 8) sleeps through the night.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The steps forward were small, but notable. INT. JAVIER & ISABEL’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS Isabel lies in bed, alone.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The therapy was working.  86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier sits at the table, drinking alone again.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Or some might argue, time was simply healing the wound. INT. MR. SACCIONE’S FARMHOUSE - CONTINUOUS Rodrigo (now 9) sits at Mr. Saccione’s desk, writing a le (in English) under Mr. Saccione’s watchful eye:

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dear Dylan. My name is Rodrigo Gonzales, but I like to be called Rod. I am from Spain. My uncle presented me--

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: (correcting) Gave me.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO, (0.S)
dialogues.text: --gave me your address to write you a letter.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. IRWIN DEMPSEY’S BROWNSTONE (NEW YORK) - DAY Irwin (Dylan’s whiskey drinking grandfather, remember him walks in the front door of his New York brownstone. He is holding THE LETTER amidst other mail. Rodrigo’s voice covers the following:

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was there the day you were born. I was on the bus. INT. IRWIN’S KITCHEN - DAY Irwin and Linda (Dylan’s grandmother) read the letter at kitchen table.  87.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wonder about you every day. Actually, I wonder about you every minute. I hope you are okay and that you are happy. INT. DYLAN DEMPSEY’S BEDROOM - DAY Linda reads the letter to Dylan (age six).

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was sad for a long time but my uncle got me a bird which helps. If you are sad maybe you can get a bird. Please write me back? I really hope very much that you are okay. Love, Rod.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DYLAN’S BEDROOM - LATER Now Dylan writes back the letter we saw her writing when first met her at six years old (after Will’s suicide). We hear her little voice through the following:

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dear Rod. I got your letter and it was very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Saccione runs through the olive grove like a giddy madman. He’s holding Dylan’s LETTER in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You spell really good my Nana says, and you seem like a very nice boy she says too. Men (working in the field) watch Mr. Saccione run, confus Javier is amongst them.  88. INT. JAVIER & ISABEL’S HOME —- CONTINUOUS Mr. Saccione bursts into the house. Isabel and Rodrigo tu He holds up the letter, excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I think you are lucky that you have a bird. I have a dog. He is my best friend. Mr. Saccione hands Rodrigo the letter. Rodrigo slowly ope it, reads.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Do you like pizza? I mainly like pizza and dogs. But dogs more. From, Dylan Dempsey. (then) P.S. - I’m okay. Thank you for asking. Rodrigo looks up from the letter, dazed. Tears well in hi eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: (realizing) She’s okay. And in that moment, we can see that Rodrigo is going to b okay, too. He walks over to his mother, repeats: RODRIGO (CONT’D) She’s okay. Isabel nods. Rodrigo hugs his mother and he starts crying This makes his mother cry, too. Mr. Saccione watches, moved. Rodrigo turns to Mr. Saccione and motions for him to join them. Mr. Saccione hesitates, then does. As they group hug, Mr. Saccione and Isabel share a charge look.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE BAY WINDOW
dialogues.text: Javier watches his family from the spot where Mr. Saccion once stood.  89. Literally on the outside, looking in. INT. MR. SACCIONE’S FARMHOUSE - DAYS LATER Mr. Saccione sits at his desk, writing.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do you love her? Mr. Saccione stops writing. He doesn’t even turn around.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: And Rodrig--

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Yes. Mr. Saccione finally turns to face his accuser. MR. SACCIONE (CONT’D) I had pure intentions. You may not believe me, but... (then) Loneliness creates weakness, Javier. I am not proud.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: But your father certainly would be. You’ve turned out to be your father’s son after all, Sir. For Mr. Saccione, this cuts deeply. He stands, approaches Javier. Mr. Saccione looks him dead the eye, determined.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: I give you my word: I will stay away from them. Your son is healing, he doesn’t need me anymore. They are your family, Javier. Not mine. He walks back to his desk and sits. But then:

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No.  90. Mr. Saccione looks up, as confused as we are.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. JAVIER’S KITCHEN - NIGHT Javier sits at the kitchen table, sipping from a bottle. Isabel enters the room, in a nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Why have you not come to bed? She notices a SUITCASE next to Javier.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: This is goodbye, Bonita. Isabel looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Javier stands, approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I see the way you look at him. And he at you. Isabel raises a brow.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Javier, you are drunk and you are jealous--

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I see what he has done for our son--

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: He helped him get better--

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: --things I could not do--

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: You did nothing, Javier! This hangs there.  91.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No? You disagree? Were you looking for answers at the bottom of those bottles? Javier stands.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: I’ve taken a job up North. TI will send you all the money. Though I suspect soon, you will not need it--

dialogues.speaker: SLAP
dialogues.text: Isabel slaps him across the face.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bonit--

dialogues.speaker: SLAP
dialogues.text: Again.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: So you just gift me to him? After all we’ve been through together... like a birthday present, you gift me!?

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: You deserve mor--

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Do not tell me what I deserve, Javier! I know what I deserve! Even as a little girl I knew! Even when my Abuela - my favorite Abuela - told me I was not special, that I was in the middle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abuela counsels little Isabel (7) - we’ve seen this befor

dialogues.speaker: ABUELA
dialogues.text: ...try not to get too fat and maybe you can even meet a man and have someone to share meals with for the rest of your life. Little Isabel nods blankly.  92. Abuela turns away. Little Isabel gives her the finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabel serves tables. All around her, MEN watch the stunning FLAMENCO DANCER on stage.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And when you think you saved me, Javier? Isabel spots YOUNG JAVIER watching the show across the ro He’s LAUGHING, and DANCING. He’s appealing.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When you think you found me, and plucked me from my miserable life, and made me whole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier laughs with FRIENDS. Into his line of vision steps Isabel. She bends over to pick up a napkin, and looks at him, coquettish.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I found you, Javier. I chose you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabel continues:

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: I chose you because I knew I deserved someone special. Someone kind, and funny... someone who laughs with his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: So look me in those eyes you love so much, Isabel! Look me in those eyes and tell me that you would have a better life with me than with him. Isabel steps right up to Javier, looks him dead in the ey

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: I would have a better life with you than with him. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now get the fuck out of my house. And as both of them register the unofficial end of their story...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Life - that unreliable, mischievous little bitch - never stops twisting our plots. (then) The inseparable, separate. (then) Unbreakable love, breaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier kisses a sleeping Rodrigo goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: More heroes exit our plays, without so much as a curtain call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabel cries to Mr. Saccione.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And supporting players suddenly take over the leads. Isabel stops crying. She stands.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Enough. For my son: enough. She wipes away her tears.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (strong) That boy is all I have. And his glass has been half empty for far too long. I do not care what he becomes, just that he finds his way. That he finds his worth. (then) You will help him find that with me.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Of cours--

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: (firm) Say it. Say you will help him find his way. Mr. Saccione looks up. He looks Isabel in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: I will help him find his way. Isabel nods, softens. She speaks gently to Mr. Saccione:

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: I will never love you as I love him. It’s unclear who Isabel is talking about: Javier or Rodri But Mr. Saccione just nods. He doesn’t care.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine-year-old Rodrigo wakes up. Puts on his sneakers.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If we’ve learned anything by now, it’s not to get too attached to new heroes. They tend to disappoint. But damn if little Rodrigo Gonzales didn’t look like the real deal. Rodrigo finishes tying his laces. He looks up at camera and...  95. The little guy winks right at us like he’s George fucking Clooney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo runs through the olive groves, a child at play. As he runs through the trees, we continually pan down to shoes, and back up to his face. Back and forth. As we do... the shoes change, and Rodrigo ages. And as Rodrigo evolves during this one single shot/run, h life plays out in voice-over:

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Where’s Papa?

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Papa went away for a bit, Hijo. Rodrigo keeps running.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (later) Where’s Papa?

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Papa is gone, Hijo. Rodrigo runs faster. His hair grows longer. He’s ten. The eleven.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now read it again, in English.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (reading) YOU don’t know about me without you have read a book by the name of The Adventures of Tom Sawyer; but that ain’t no matter. Rodrigo starts filling out, running harder. He becomes a teen... twelve, then thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rodrigo is my finest student, Ms. Gonzales.  96.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: The most popular boy in my class.

dialogues.speaker: COACH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A tremendous athlete your son. A gifted runner. Running faster and faster now. He turns into a muscular teenager... fourteen, fifteen, sixteen...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Are you a virgin?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Would you like not to be? Now he’s a fully-grown eighteen year old. Movie star handsome. He’s no longer running through the olive groves for “play Now he’s running for sport. Driven.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We think he can get an academic scholarship.

dialogues.speaker: COACH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We think he can get an athletic scholarship.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where do you want to go to school, Rodrigo?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: America. Rodrigo is running top speed now. Muscles churning. His face spreads into a huge smile as he spots... THE FARMHOUSE. He’s running home. And he has news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bursts in the door.  97.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: Mama!? Vincent!?

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We’re upstairs. Rodrigo throws down his bag. He bolts through the house.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: (calling out) I got in! NYU! Early Admission!

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: New York had once captivated Rodrigo’s imagination, then haunted it, and eventually captivated it again. Rodrigo takes the stairs, two at a time...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So it came as no surprise that he would be subconsciously drawn back to the city one day. (then) But life tends not to forecast its biggest surprises. Rodrigo enters a bedroom to find... ISABEL and MR. SACCIONE (both aged nine years) sitting on bed. They've been crying. Rodrigo stops in his tracks. They look up at him.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: I’m sick, Hijo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo, Isabel, and Mr. Saccione eat at the kitchen tabl silence. Finally, Rodrigo puts down his fork.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: I will delay University. I will stay home until you are better.  98.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: (gentle) It is not your decision, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Isabel, with all that is happening--

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: I said no.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: (again, firmly) And I said that it is not your decision. Isabel looks up, surprised at her son’s tone. RODRIGO (CONT’D) You have given me everything, Mama. You have given me your life. I can give you this.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: Hij--

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: (firm) I can give you this. He leans in. Takes their hands. RODRIGO (CONT’D) We will fix this, Mama. We will fix this the way you fixed me. Look at me. Both of you, look at me. (then) We will fix you. Mr. Saccione nods. He squeezes Rodrigo’s hand. As they sit there like this, our Narrator repeats an earl sentiment:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Money cannot buy happiness. But good health, is sometimes very much for sale.  99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabel receives chemo.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But not always. She looks awful. Mr. Saccione looks on, confused. This isn’t how it is supposed to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo tends to his mother, wetting her lips with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo (now sporting a mustache) and Mr. Saccione play c in silence. Waiting for something to change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo (now with a young man’s sparse beard) picks olive the same way his father once did... by hand, into a bucke All around him, men use the more typical (and faster) techniques involving rakes and nets.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DISTANCE
dialogues.text: Mr. Saccione watches Rodrigo. He smiles sadly. For many reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo reads by the fire. Mr. Saccione steps into the ro

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Your mother asks for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo stops at the door, looks in at his mother. What we see is shocking:  100. Isabel has been ravaged by cancer. Bald. Almost unrecognizable. She motions for Rodrigo to come closer. He does. She spea quietly.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: It has been two years, Hijo. I do not get better. Vincent spends enough so I do not get worse. I just... survive. And you just wait. It is enough.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: Mama-—

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: (lovingly) It is enough, Hijo. (then) Listen to me, come here. She pulls him toward her. She starts talking, very softly We do not translate this. We do not need to. She is telli him to leave her. And as the mother releases the son from his duty... the s cries. He cries because what she says is powerful and because he knows she is right. It is time for Rodrigo Gonzales to start his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo sits in a class, taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rodrigo entered NYU a twenty-one- year-old freshman. And as he’d been doing for most of the previous decade, he thrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cross-country track meet. Rodrigo bursts from the woods, running in a full sprint. flies past camera.  101. It takes ten seconds for anyone else to even emerge from woods.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He lettered in two sports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo gives a presentation.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: His marks were at the very top of his class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo fools around with an attractive girl.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He even embarked on a relationship with a nineteen-year-old Jewish American Princess from Long Island named Shari Dickstein. She made him laugh. Usually not intentionally. Shari breaks from their kiss.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Oh my gawd, I totally forgot to tell you, I was at Whole Foods, and Rina Rothman was there - such a pig - anyway-- As Shari continues (and Rodrigo suppresses a laugh):

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She wasn’t his great love, but she was company, and great love wasn’t his priority at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo sits in economy class, sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He saved every dollar, coveted every vacation. Rodrigo Gonzales had an internal compass, and it always pointed in the same direction.  102. INT. BEDROOM —- MORNING Rodrigo sits by the bedside of his mother, entertaining h Mr. Saccione sits on the other side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: She’s from a place called Long Island. Her name is Shari Dickstein... He shows a picture from his phone.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: But what is she like, Hijo? Tell me. Rodrigo thinks for a beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: She’s loud. Isabel and Mr. Saccione explode LAUGHING.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Like so many of the biggest years of our lives, it flew by. But in truth, that year was just a setup - a preamble to the biggest day of Rodrigo Gonzales’ life: March 31st, 2032. CHYRON: MARCH 31st, 2032.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo lies next to Shari. He’s awake. She's asleep, snoring. He watches her, thinking. He stands, starts dressing. Shari stirs.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: Just going for a quick run. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Bonita.  103.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: When we started dating you called me “Bonita.” You would have said: “Just going for a quick run, Bonita.” (then) It always made me feel like Kelly Ripa. A loaded beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: Shari--

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: I’m pregnant. Fuck. Rodrigo’s world spins like a top. Shari sits up, starts dressing.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know. Lots to talk about, obvi. Hey - will you take me for brunch? There’s this place I want to try, it’s Vietnamese, I’m assuming that’s like Dim Sum or something but I’m dying to try it. Rodrigo just stands there, speechless.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can talk at brunch. At the Vietnamese place. I really want to try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo and Shari walk down the city street. Shari talks a mile a minute. Rodrigo just stares, lost.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: So I just started feeling shitty a few weeks ago. I thought I was just getting a really bad period, ever since I got off the pill I’ve been getting bananas periods, you know? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SHARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it wasn’t stopping so I went to my gyno and he was like “are you sexually active” and I told him about you and then he did the test thing and blammo. I hadn’t even thought to try an at-home test, for whatever reason my brain didn’t go there what-so-fucking-ever. Beat. Rodrigo just stares. She continues, nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyways, I know we haven’t been together very long and clearly this is as what-the-fuck as you get. I don’t really know what your deal is with religious stuff, but I think I should probably just get an abortion. She turns back to him. SHARI (CONT’D) Are you like super against that? Abortion? Shari has stopped out in the street, looking back at Rodr Rodrigo, still speechless, looks to her right. A TAXI is speeding down the side street right at her. SHARI (CONT’D) I know abortion’s a big thing for Christians - you’re Christian I assu-— At the last second, Rodrigo grabs her arm and pulls her b to safety. The CABBIE blares on his horn. Shari barely notices.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyhow, we don’t have to decide all this now, but I would like to make the call early before the thing has a head and stuff. Rodrigo stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shari eats noodles sloppily.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: So the way I see it, we have like three options... She SLURPS. Rodrigo’s brain explodes with each slurp.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Option One: we have it. I mean, a mixed race baby with our skin complexions would be amazeballs. My family has batshit money, we could get nannies and stuff, I don’t know, probably a bad idea. SLURP. Brain explosion.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Option Two: abort. But again, I'd like to make that call sooner than later before the thing has a head and stuff. SLURP. Brain explosion.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or Option Three: we can just agree this is all an insane APRIL FOOL'S

dialogues.speaker: JOKE
dialogues.text: A long beat of silence.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: (confused) What?

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: April Fool's, Bitch!

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Seriously? You don’t know April Fool's? Rodrigo stares blankly at her.  106. SHARI (CONT’D) On the first day of April you play practical jokes on people and yell April Fool’s!

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: But it’s March 31st.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: I thought you'd see it coming if I did it on April Fool's Day.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: I didn’t even know what April Fool’s Day was.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Well I didn’t know that. Rodrigo processes.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: So there’s no baby?

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Dude, no! Oh c’mon, that was funny! You have to admit, that was funny. Rodrigo puts down his napkin. Breathes deeply.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: Shari--

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Oh fuck, you’re going to break up with me aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was. As we watch Rodrigo do the deed...

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Obviously nothing thus far had indicated that March 31st would be the most important day of Rodrigo’s life. The entire day - as so many of life’s days are - had been a misdirect. A fake out. Literally... Shari is hysterical.  107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We take in the familiar farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, sometimes the most important days of our lives begin, and we’re not even there to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nurse cares for Isabel. Mr. Saccione helps the nurse. T room is filled with a quiet desperation. Isabel Gonzales is dying.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: I must call Rodrigo. Isabel shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pleading) Isabel.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: (weakly) Let him be young for one more day. He will come after.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: Isabel--

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: No. Not like this. Isabel touches Mr. Saccione’s arm. He looks at her for a long, silent beat.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are a good man, Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: You are. (then, again) You are. He’s emotional now. They sit there like that for quite a while, just looking one another, saying a silent goodbye. A silent thank you. And then:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello, Isabel. They look up. Standing at the doorway is Javier, Rodrigo’s father. He h aged 13 years since we last saw him. He looks to Mr. Saccione, nods.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All of life’s surprises are not bad ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Saccione WRITES A LETTER at his desk. Note: This is how we first met him, all those years ago.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Saccione was a letter writer. He always had been. He believed in the power of the written word, the force of actually sitting down and writing to someone by hand. (then) The bulk of Mr. Saccione’s letters were to one man: We see the letter heading: Dear Papa. NARRATOR (CONT’D) Almost every day - his own private therapy - he would write to his deceased father. He would release his anger about his abusive upbringing. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NARRATOR (CONT’D) About what it had done to him, and to his mother. And then... Mr. Saccione finishes the letter. Signs it. And throws it in the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’ve seen this scene before: Mr. Saccione giving little Rodrigo (9) a bird:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: But as Rodrigo started healing, so did Mr. Saccione.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The desk (and pen) sits, unused.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: The letter writing slowed. Then stopped. Until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’ve seen this before, too. Javier and Mr. Saccione confront one another that fateful night (right before Javier makes his choice to leave)

dialogues.speaker: MR. SACCIONE
dialogues.text: (to Javier) I give you my word: I will stay away from them. Your son is healing, he doesn’t need me anymore. They are your family, Javier. Not mine. He walks back to his desk and sits. But then:

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: No. Mr. Saccione looks up, as confused as we are. The rest of this scene we haven’t seen yet...  110.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They are better off with you. I cannot help my son the way you can. And I have already lost my wife, even though she will deny it. I will not return. I will not confuse things. (then) I ask only one favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Saccione writes letters. Tons of letters. He writes about Rodrigo, about Isabel, about his olives.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: And with that, Mr. Saccione’s letters found a new recipient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier, taking a break from work, reads under a tree.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: A man whose only request was that he be kept up to date on those he had abandoned, but still cherished.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE LETTER
dialogues.text: The bottom of it reads: “She is dying, Javier. Come home.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. ISABEL’S ROOM - PRESENT DAY Isabel looks at Javier, stunned to see him. Her eyes well with tears. Javier's do, too. He steps to the other side of her bed (opposite Mr. Saccione). He sits. His voice breaks as he says...

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: Hello, Bonita.  111. Isabel is crying now. She reaches out slowly. Takes Javier’s hand. She reaches out her other hand. Takes Mr. Saccione’s. As she says goodbye to the two men who loved her we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo, fresh from his “break up,” walks back into his r As he does, his cell phone RINGS. The caller reads: “Tio” (Uncle). Rodrigo answers. We can tell, immediately, that he is getting the bad news. His mother has died. CUE SONG: “To Make You Feel My Love” by BOB DYLAN. The song takes over as we watch Rodrigo receive the news. OVER THE NEXT FEW HOURS we watch him process. He cries. He paces. He sits. He thinks. He grieves. All to “To Make You Feel My Love.”

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: When critics reviewed Abby Dempsey’s favorite album - Bob Dylan’s 1997 release, Time out of Mind - the song “To Make You Feel My Love” was the source of much criticism. Every track on the album brimmed with unrelenting melancholy and sadness. But there, smack in the middle of it all, sat an unabashedly populist hit song. A love song. A song that in years to come would be covered by Garth Brooks, of all people. Critics argued that putting an on-the-nose love song in the middle of an album about despair and tragedy, was Dylan's only misstep. (then) Others argued that it was his point.  112. Rodrigo stands. He puts on running shoes. He needs to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodrigo runs through the night, flying past pedestrians o the New York City sidewalks. He runs and runs and runs. He’s trying to outrun his loss his grief.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Rodrigo Gonzales had not returned to the corner of 32nd and 3rd until that night. He’d started a new chapter in New York, and hadn’t felt a need to re-open his saddest one. (then) But that night he wanted to be sad. Rodrigo stops in his tracks. He is looking at something. Or someone.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Does it matter? REVEAL: Dylan Dempsey, 18 years old. Dylan is standing exactly where we left her - at the stre corner where her mother died. She turns toward Rodrigo. Just like her long lost maternal grandmother before her, Dylan has taken a bite of her peanut butter and jelly sandwich at the exact moment she’s met a boy. She holds up her hand, silently asking for a moment, tryi to get down her sandwich as she quickly wipes off her mas streaked face. Rodrigo cocks his head, takes her in.  113.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: My father, Rodrigo Gonzales, officially met my mother, Dylan Dempsey that day - the most important day of his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ATTRACTIVE WOMAN (30s) stands on stage. This is our narrator.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: They would not spend a single night apart for the next 42 years. This is high-end BOOK READING. And from signage, we see t the woman is reading from her own novel: LIFE, ITSELF (an unreliable memoir) by Elena Gonzales- Dempsey.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: (trying again) They would go on to have four children, seven grandchildren. A love story for the ages. She looks out...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CROWD
dialogues.text: At Dylan and Rodrigo. We recognize them instantly, even though they’re now deep in their 60s.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ELENA
dialogues.text: She continues reading.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My grandmother, Abby Dempsey, argued in her failed college thesis that life itself is our most unreliable narrator. She argued that one never knows where their story is going, nor who the heroes of it are going to be. (beat, then) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks 114.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And while it’s true that life has often made it difficult to pinpoint the heroes of my family’s story, my parents have always made it incredibly easy for me. back out at them.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My parents found the populist love song in the middle of our family’s often very melancholy album. Out in the crowd: Rodrigo smiles, takes Dylan’s hand. Elena smiles back at them, continues reading:

dialogues.speaker: ELENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wonder sometimes what my grandmother Abby would have made of that, philosophically. That her own child - the girl she named after her favorite gravel voiced musician - found a love story with no twists, no plot turns, and no surprises. Just consistency. Oh, what I’d have given to have met her. To have told her that. To have told her that we were all okay. (then) And what I’d have given to have met my grandmother Isabel as well. Unlike Abby, she was neither a writer nor a philosopher. But sometimes I wonder if she didn’t understand exactly what Bob Dylan was going for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back with Isabel, sick in bed, saying goodbye to tw one-year-old Rodrigo before sending him off to NYU. This is the scene we didn’t translate before.

dialogues.speaker: RODRIGO
dialogues.text: Mama-—  115.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: (lovingly) It is enough, Hijo. (then) Listen to me, come here. She pulls him toward her. She starts talking, very softly

dialogues.speaker: ELENA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Spanish does not often translate perfectly, but what Isabel said that day to her son - my father - it required no translation. Note: this is the same speech we saw earlier in Spanish without translation, but now it is actually delivered by Isabel in English.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL
dialogues.text: You have had many ups and downs in your life, Hijo. Too many. And you will have more. This is life. This is what it does. Life brings you to your knees. It brings you lower than you think you can go. But if you stand back up and move forward - if you go just a little further - you will always find love. (then) I found love in you, Hijo. And my life - my story - it will continue after I am gone. You, Hijo, are my story. You are your father’s story. You are your uncle’s. Rodrigo is crying now.

dialogues.speaker: ISABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My body fails me, Hijo. But you ARE me. So you go now. Give me a beautiful life. And when life takes us to our knees, you stand us back up. You get up, and go further, and find us the love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Elena continues:  116.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: I am not sure whose story I have been telling. I am not sure it is mine, or if it some character’s who we've not met yet. I’m not sure of anything. All I know, is that at any moment, life will surprise me. It will bring me to my knees. And when it does. When I think I cannot recover, I will remind myself... She looks out, finds her parents.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will remind myself that I am my father. That I am my father’s father. And I am my mother, and my mother’s mother. I am their story, and they are mine. And while it may be easy to wallow in the tragedies that shape our lives... while it’s natural to focus on those unspeakable moments that bring us to our knees... we must remind ourselves that if we get up, if we just take the story a little bit further... She is crying now. She looks directly at her parents.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we go far enough, there is love. Her parents are crying now, too.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (again) If we go far enough, there’s love. Elena closes her book. Rodrigo and Dylan beam at their youngest daughter, the la hero in our ever-evolving story. And with that, our story does what our story never really does... It ends. FADE TO BLACK.
